item.title: Viking Tactics RPG Norse: Oath of Blood Delayed on PC and Consoles
item.content:encoded:
Upcoming Viking tactics RPG Norse: Oath of Blood has been delayed on both PC and consoles, and while PC players won't have to wait too much longer to check the game out, it'll be a bit of a longer delay for PS5 and Xbox.

Originally set to launch on February 3rd, Norse: Oath of Blood will now be arriving on February 17th on Steam, Epic, and GOG, which represents a delay of just two weeks. That's not too bad, if you ask me.

The PS5 and Xbox Series X|S versions of the game were initially due to arrive alongside the PC launch, but that's no longer happening; instead, console players will have to wait until spring to check out Norse: Oath of Blood.

Arctic Hazard explains the delay over on Bluesky, but it's a fairly standard explanation; the devs need more time to "further refine and polish the experience" of Norse: Oath of Blood so that it reflects the studio's "passion for the source material".

Although the game is being delayed, Arctic Hazard and Tripwire are promising new developer diaries in the coming weeks, which will include "behind-the-scenes looks at development, deeper dives into gameplay, and additional updates".

If you're not familiar with Norse: Oath of Blood, it's a gritty tactical RPG that emphasizes down-to-earth realism in a way that I suspect Wartales fans will appreciate.

You play as a young Viking called Gunnar (because of course he is), who's out for vengeance after his home is destroyed by the intimidating-sounding Steinarr Far-Spear. You must build a settlement from scratch, training warriors and assigning villagers as you go.

Norse: Oath of Blood will be launching on PC via Steam, GOG, and Epic on February 17th, and it'll be arriving on PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X|S at some point this spring. Stay tuned for more.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Quantic Dream's Spellcasters Chronicles Lands February Early Access Date
item.content:encoded:
On a scale of one to ten, how desperate would you say you are to try out Heavy Rain studio Quantic Dream's new multiplayer action-strategy game Spellcasters Chronicles? Well, it's launching in February, at any rate.

Per a press release, Spellcasters Chronicles' Early Access period starts on February 26th, but before that date rolls around, there's a second closed beta to participate in should you wish to. That kicks off on January 29th and comes to an end on February 2nd.

As for what you can expect from the competitive multiplayer title's second beta, Quantic Dream says the game will come complete with "a range of new content and technical improvements", including a new map and more.

The new map is The Nordic Shore, a five-lane arena with "open sightlines, harsh environmental conditions, and a unique pattern" for players to get to grips with.

It's joined by a new in-game intro and tutorial to help new players get into Spellcasters Chronicles, as well as in-game text chat for teams, a player reporting system (for such a thing must come alongside text chat), and customization for spellcasters.

Of course, since there is now customization, there must also be microtransactions, and so this update is also introducing a range of cosmetic packs you can buy, with costs ranging from $8.99 to a slightly alarming $69.99.

Quantic Dream has also altered the system specs for Spellcasters Chronicles for this beta. Revised specs are as follows.

Minimum

  • CPU: Intel Core i5-10400 or AMD Ryzen 5 2600
  • GPU: Nvidia GeForce RTX 2070 or AMD Radeon RX 5700
  • 16GB RAM, NVMe SSD, Windows 11

Recommended

  • CPU: Intel Core i7-10700K or AMD Ryzen 7 2700
  • GPU: Nvidia GeForce RTX 3070 or AMD Radeon RX 9060 XT
  • 16GB RAM, NVMe SSD, Windows 11

As for Quantic Dream's other project, Star Wars Eclipse, there's still no news, unfortunately, although Quantic Dream did apparently manage to escape the recent NetEase employee and studio purge, so that's something, at least.

Spellcasters Chronicles launches in Early Access on PC via Steam on February 26th. Stay tuned for more.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Bubsy 4D Release Date Lets the Cat Out of the Bag in May
item.content:encoded:
Developer Fabraz and publisher Atari have revealed the Bubsy 4D release date, so if you think everyone's (least?) favorite bobcat deserves one more shot, then it's nearly time to put your money where your mouth is.

As revealed by Atari on social media, Bubsy 4D will be arriving on PC and consoles on May 22nd, and if, for some reason, you'd like to pre-order the game, you can do so now on your platform of choice.

It's no secret that Bubsy games aren't exactly well-received by and large, but Fabraz, whose name you might recognize from 3D platformer Demon Turf and 2D offering Slime-san, is hoping it can change all that.

This time around, Bubsy is making a return to 3D, which feels like a pretty ballsy move given how things went for the bobcat's last excursion into the third dimension.

As you'd probably expect (and as is probably necessary given Bubsy's history), Bubsy 4D is taking a self-aware approach; Bubsy himself is returning to the fold after a long absence, and characters around him frequently question whether he's up to the job.

The game itself is a fairly straightforward 3D collectathon platformer in which Bubsy must navigate a series of "expansive craft-themed levels" and do battle with vicious BaaBots in order to recover his beloved Golden Fleece.

You can check out the new release date announcement trailer for Bubsy 4D right here. It gives a sense of what kind of gameplay you can expect if you decide to humor the bobcat one last time.

I've been talking smack about Bubsy for this whole piece, but I won't lie: I'm actually rooting for Fabraz and Atari on this one, because I played the Bubsy 4D demo, and it's...well, it's quite fun. Don't tell anyone I said that.

In any case, Bubsy 4D launches for PC, PlayStation, Xbox, and both Switch 2 and Switch on May 22nd. Stay tuned to find out whether it's actually decent like the demo.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph
